title: Proton-Pump Inhibitor Use and Gastrointestinal Disease Risk: A Mendelian Randomization Study of Omics and Pharmacological Pathways.
abstract: While proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) show epidemiological associations with gastrointestinal disorders, their mechanistic basis remains unclear. The pharmacological effects of a drug are determined not only by its direct protein targets but also by genes involved in its metabolism and transport. Using two-sample Mendelian randomization and multi-ancestry cohorts (UKB/FinnGen), we systematically assessed genes encoding both direct targets of PPIs and key proteins involved in PPI pharmacokinetics across 24 gastrointestinal diseases. Validation included colocalization/SMR analyses, disease stratification, anatomical stratification, and HPA-based tissue expression profiling. Single-cell sequencing further elucidated target distribution. Finally, meta-analysis validates the correlation between PPI and gastrointestinal disorders.
